docs.snippet: The political convulsion that swept Buenos Aires late last week, resulting in the ouster of President Leopoldo Galtieri, seemed to the British to open up the possibility of a fresh start in the South Atlantic. With General Galtieri still in office...
docs.lead_paragraph: The political convulsion that swept Buenos Aires late last week, resulting in the ouster of President Leopoldo Galtieri, seemed to the British to open up the possibility of a fresh start in the South Atlantic. With General Galtieri still in office and worried about his personal honor, it had seemed that the British military triumph might be followed by months of pointless wrangling and indecision. No one in Whitehall thinks the coming months will be easy, a Cabinet minister said on Friday, ''but at least we can get on with it, and at least we don't have to worry about the prisoners any more.'' After General Galtieri resigned, Argentina decided to facilitate return of most of the more than 10,000 captives taken after Stanley fell.

headline.main: FOR BRITAIN AND THE FALKLANDS, THE POSTWAR WORLD IS SHAKY

docs.snippet: Argentina's military leaders continued their search for a new President for the country today amid signs they remained seriously split over the choice.   The three-member junta met at 4:30 P.M., but recessed less than two hours later. Each member...
docs.lead_paragraph: Argentina's military leaders continued their search for a new President for the country today amid signs they remained seriously split over the choice. The three-member junta met at 4:30 P.M., but recessed less than two hours later. Each member returned to his headquarters to consult with ranking leaders of his branch of service. They scheduled another meeting for Monday morning.

headline.main: ARGENTINES STRUGGLE TO PICK A LEADER

byline.original: By RICHARD J. MEISLIN, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Yesterday was the 32d anniversary of the greatest triumph by the United States in international soccer, considered one of the biggest upsets in World Cup history. On June 29, 1950, the United States team, composed of men who played together only once...
docs.lead_paragraph: Yesterday was the 32d anniversary of the greatest triumph by the United States in international soccer, considered one of the biggest upsets in World Cup history. On June 29, 1950, the United States team, composed of men who played together only once before going to Argentina for the cup, upset England, 1-0.

byline.original: By Lawrie Mifflin and Michale Katz

docs.snippet: WHEN Mona Doyle, a marketing pollster, asks people if they want alternatives to the chemical preservatives in their food, most of them say yes. When she asks if they want fruits, vegetables and meat that stay fresher longer, they say yes.   But when...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Mona Doyle, a marketing pollster, asks people if they want alternatives to the chemical preservatives in their food, most of them say yes. When she asks if they want fruits, vegetables and meat that stay fresher longer, they say yes. But when she mentions a preservation technique that promises to make those things possible, they respond, she says, by asking such half-serious questions as ''Does it make you glow in the dark?'' The technique is irradiation - exposing foods to gamma rays or electrons emitted by radioactive materials - and it may soon do to some consumer foods in this country what it has long done to cosmetics, hospital equipment, baby powders and meals astronauts have eaten on the moon and in orbit: kill off substantial amounts of bacteria in food or sterilize it altogether. The food itself does not become radioactive, just as dental and chest X-rays do not make teeth and lungs radioactive. In low doses, irradiation has little effect on taste.

docs.snippet: Following is a list, made public by Pan American World Airways, of crew members and passengers killed in Friday's jetliner crash near New Orleans. The list was provided by The Associated Press, which said that some name duplications might be...
docs.lead_paragraph: Following is a list, made public by Pan American World Airways, of crew members and passengers killed in Friday's jetliner crash near New Orleans. The list was provided by The Associated Press, which said that some name duplications might be explained because one person bought two or more tickets. Crew McCULLARS, Kenneth L., captain, Sebastian, Fla. PIERCE, Donald G., first officer, Miami Lakes, NOONE, Leo B., flight engineer, Miami. DONNELLY, Dennis M., purser, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. FIJUT, James P., flight attendant, Miramar, Fla. BROWN, Lucille, flight attendant, Hollywood, Fla. FORD, Vivian L., flight attendant, West Hollywood, Fla.

headline.main: LIST OF THOSE ABOARD PLANE THAT CRASHED NEAR NEW ORLEANS

docs.snippet: The International Whaling Commission voted today to ban all commercial whaling, starting in 1986.  The 25-to-7 vote, taken at the commission's session in Brighton, England, does not necessarily mean an end to the killing of whales.  Participants at...
docs.lead_paragraph: The International Whaling Commission voted today to ban all commercial whaling, starting in 1986. The 25-to-7 vote, taken at the commission's session in Brighton, England, does not necessarily mean an end to the killing of whales. Participants at the commission's meeting said some of the nations that opposed the ban, including Japan and Norway, had threatened to file exceptions to the decision and continue to hunt whales.

headline.main: COMMISSION VOTES TO BAN HUNTING OF WHALES

byline.original: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: One month after the end of hostilities here, Falkland Islanders seem convinced that they will never again experience the way of life that Britain fought to maintain.   The muddy streets and fields of Stanley will be cleared within three months of...
docs.lead_paragraph: One month after the end of hostilities here, Falkland Islanders seem convinced that they will never again experience the way of life that Britain fought to maintain. The muddy streets and fields of Stanley will be cleared within three months of seven million rounds of live ammunition, but it may not be for years, if ever, that as many as 12,000 mines can be removed. They include small plastic devices scattered from helicopters in the final days of the war with Argentina. Children, who have come to call them ''green pebbles,'' are kept at home by fearful parents. Jeanne Sheridan, a mother of two, said, ''We'll never be able to cross those fields to gather teaberries again.'' Because of the mines, there is no driving outside of Stanley, no fishing and no collection of peat, which is used for heating.

headline.main: UNEASE INVADES FALKLANDS IN WAR AFTERMATH

byline.original: By JAMES FERON, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Sixth-seeded Tim Wilkison was upset by Erick Iskersky, 6-1, 7-5, today as play began in the $150.000 Mutual Benefit Life Open tennis tournament.   In losing to the 24-year-old Iskersky, a singles finalist for Trinity University of Texas in the 1979...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sixth-seeded Tim Wilkison was upset by Erick Iskersky, 6-1, 7-5, today as play began in the $150.000 Mutual Benefit Life Open tennis tournament. In losing to the 24-year-old Iskersky, a singles finalist for Trinity University of Texas in the 1979 National Collegiate Athletic Association championships, Wilkison dropped the last 12 points. Trailing by 5-4 in the concluding set, Iskersky, of Rossford, Ohio, lost the first point of the 10th game on his service. But he was the master of his opponent after that. After taking the 10th game, he broke service, with Wilkison double-faulting twice.

headline.main: WILKISON IS UPSET IN JERSEY BY 6-1, 7-5

byline.original: By MICHAEL STRAUSS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: SIMONSSON UPSETS VILAS IN CLAY COURT   INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 3 (AP) - Hans Simonsson, a 20-year-old Swedish Davis Cup player, upset top-seeded Guillermo Vilas, 6-4, 6-1, tonight in the second round of the United States Clay Court Championships.   ''This...
docs.lead_paragraph: SIMONSSON UPSETS VILAS IN CLAY COURT INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 3 (AP) - Hans Simonsson, a 20-year-old Swedish Davis Cup player, upset top-seeded Guillermo Vilas, 6-4, 6-1, tonight in the second round of the United States Clay Court Championships. ''This is probably the best I've played ever,'' said Simonsson, who was No. 245 in the recent computer ranking by the Association of Tennis Professionals. ''I worked on his backhand because his forehand is very good.''

docs.snippet: Political opponents are abducted, often never to be seen again, in 22 countries around the world, 10 of them in Latin America, according to United Nations human rights experts.   The practice, known formally as political disappearances, is so...
docs.lead_paragraph: Political opponents are abducted, often never to be seen again, in 22 countries around the world, 10 of them in Latin America, according to United Nations human rights experts. The practice, known formally as political disappearances, is so widespread that governments should establish special safeguards to fight it, the United Nations Human Rights Committee said in its annual report. The report, to be officially presented to the General Assembly later this year, branded disappearances as a euphemism for terror campaigns often led by police, military or paramilitary forces.
